title: Embedded shaders
body:
When trying to run either examples or own projects linking to the library it woudl seem that the default shaders were not embedded properly as it fails to load them in all cases resulting in a black window. Here is an example of the output from the basic example with it being the same for my own built.

```
INFO: SHADER: [ID 4] Vertex shader compiled successfully
INFO: SHADER: [ID 5] Fragment shader compiled successfully
WARNING: SHADER: [ID 6] Failed to link shader program
WARNING: SHADER: [ID 6] Link error: ERROR: Linking vertex stage: Missing entry point: Each stage requires one entry point
ERROR: Linking fragment stage: Missing entry point: Each stage requires one entry point

WARNING: SHADER: Failed to load custom shader code, using default shader
INFO: SHADER: [ID 4] Vertex shader compiled successfully
INFO: SHADER: [ID 5] Fragment shader compiled successfully
WARNING: SHADER: [ID 6] Failed to link shader program
WARNING: SHADER: [ID 6] Link error: ERROR: Linking vertex stage: Missing entry point: Each stage requires one entry point
ERROR: Linking fragment stage: Missing entry point: Each stage requires one entry point

WARNING: SHADER: Failed to load custom shader code, using default shader
```

Building on windows using cmake and Mingw. Only special flags for cmake differing from the build instrcutions are `-G "MinGW Makefiles" -DPYTHON_EXECUTABLE=python`. As it would seem that when building it was looking for python3 while I do indeed have python 3.12 the naming was different.
author: R2Sam

comments.body:
~Can you directly copy/paste the generated file or tell me what’s inside?
It should be located in your build directory at `generated/src/embedded/r3d_shaders.c`
If there was an error with Python, it should be present in the strings instead of the minified GLSL code~

**EDIT**: I just tried with the same command as you: `-G "MinGW Makefiles" -DPYTHON_EXECUTABLE=python`

The issue seems to come from `-DPYTHON_EXECUTABLE=python`

Even though `python` appears to be an alias for `python3` on my system, for some reason, this prevents the generation, no errors, nothing...

In any case, you shouldn’t need to specify python in cmake.
It should be found automatically if it’s in your `PATH` variable:  
```cmake
find_program(PYTHON_EXECUTABLE python3 REQUIRED)
```

Unless you have a particular setup with your installation?

Let me know if removing `-DPYTHON_EXECUTABLE=python` solves the issue

And just to be sure, check the generated file in your cmake build directory:  `generated/src/embedded/r3d_shaders.c`  

Make sure you’re getting the same result as me, empty strings...

satisfaction_conditions: Identification of the root cause preventing shader embedding
A working configuration for building the library with proper shader embedding
Clear guidance on CMake configuration for the library

_classification.category: Can be dockerized without any issue
